title: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Continuing Education Activity
content: Non-gonococcal urethritis (NGU), inflammation of the urethra, is the most common sexually transmitted illness in men. Urethritis can be infectious or non-infectious. Infectious causes almost always sexually transmitted. Sexually transmitted urethritis is traditionally divided into 2 categories: gonococcal urethritis and non-gonococcal urethritis (NGU). This activity describes the etiology and pathophysiology of non-gonococcal urethritis and highlights the role of the interprofessional team in its management.
contents: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Continuing Education Activity. Non-gonococcal urethritis (NGU), inflammation of the urethra, is the most common sexually transmitted illness in men. Urethritis can be infectious or non-infectious. Infectious causes almost always sexually transmitted. Sexually transmitted urethritis is traditionally divided into 2 categories: gonococcal urethritis and non-gonococcal urethritis (NGU). This activity describes the etiology and pathophysiology of non-gonococcal urethritis and highlights the role of the interprofessional team in its management.

title: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Continuing Education Activity
content: Objectives: Identify the etiology of Non-gonococcal urethritis. Review the presentation of Non-gonococcal urethritis. Outline the treatment and management options available for Non-gonococcal urethritis. Describe some interprofessional team strategies for improving care coordination and outcomes in patients with non-gonococcal urethritis. Access free multiple choice questions on this topic.
contents: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Continuing Education Activity. Objectives: Identify the etiology of Non-gonococcal urethritis. Review the presentation of Non-gonococcal urethritis. Outline the treatment and management options available for Non-gonococcal urethritis. Describe some interprofessional team strategies for improving care coordination and outcomes in patients with non-gonococcal urethritis. Access free multiple choice questions on this topic.

title: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Introduction
content: Non-gonococcal urethritis (NGU), inflammation of the urethra, is the most common sexually transmitted illness in men. Urethritis can be infectious or non-infectious. Infectious causes almost always sexually transmitted. Sexually transmitted urethritis is traditionally divided into 2 categories: gonococcal urethritis and non-gonococcal urethritis (NGU). [1] Since almost all urethritis patients have penile discharge, gonococcal urethritis can easily be distinguished from NGU by looking for gram-negative diplococci on a gram stain. If diplococci are identified, the urethritis is gonococcal; if no diplococci are identified, the diagnosis is classified as NGU. [2]
contents: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Introduction. Non-gonococcal urethritis (NGU), inflammation of the urethra, is the most common sexually transmitted illness in men. Urethritis can be infectious or non-infectious. Infectious causes almost always sexually transmitted. Sexually transmitted urethritis is traditionally divided into 2 categories: gonococcal urethritis and non-gonococcal urethritis (NGU). [1] Since almost all urethritis patients have penile discharge, gonococcal urethritis can easily be distinguished from NGU by looking for gram-negative diplococci on a gram stain. If diplococci are identified, the urethritis is gonococcal; if no diplococci are identified, the diagnosis is classified as NGU. [2]

title: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Etiology
content: The most common cause of NGU is Chlamydia trachomatis , which accounts for 15% to 40% of NGU cases. [2] The second most common cause is Mycoplasma genitalium , which accounts for 15% to 20% of NGU cases; although widespread testing for mycoplasma is not available. [3] Less common causes of NGU include infection with Trichomonas vaginalis , herpes simplex virus, Epstein Barr virus, and Adenovirus . Enteric bacteria is an uncommon cause of NGU that is typically seen in males who practice insertive anal intercourse. In almost half of all cases of NGU, an etiology is not identified. [2]
contents: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Etiology. The most common cause of NGU is Chlamydia trachomatis , which accounts for 15% to 40% of NGU cases. [2] The second most common cause is Mycoplasma genitalium , which accounts for 15% to 20% of NGU cases; although widespread testing for mycoplasma is not available. [3] Less common causes of NGU include infection with Trichomonas vaginalis , herpes simplex virus, Epstein Barr virus, and Adenovirus . Enteric bacteria is an uncommon cause of NGU that is typically seen in males who practice insertive anal intercourse. In almost half of all cases of NGU, an etiology is not identified. [2]

title: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Epidemiology
content: Urethritis is the most common sexually transmitted infection in men with gonorrhea and chlamydia representing the primary pathogens. The Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) does not publish rates of urethritis as a syndrome. The CDC instead breaks down sexual infection rates down by etiology. Chlamydia is the most commonly reported sexually transmitted infection in the United States with over 1,500,000 new cases in 2016. Rates of new diagnoses continue to rise annually with an estimated increase of 4.7% from 2015 to 2016. Trends show that rates of chlamydia in females are 2 times higher than that of males. Rates are highest among adolescents and young adults. Racial disparities exist, and blacks are 5.6 times more commonly affected with chlamydia when compared to whites. Gonorrhea cases are more commonly seen in males, and there were an estimated 468,000 new cases of gonorrhea in 2016. Like with chlamydia, infections rates are higher in adolescents and young adults; the African American race is also disproportionately affected.
contents: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Epidemiology. Urethritis is the most common sexually transmitted infection in men with gonorrhea and chlamydia representing the primary pathogens. The Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) does not publish rates of urethritis as a syndrome. The CDC instead breaks down sexual infection rates down by etiology. Chlamydia is the most commonly reported sexually transmitted infection in the United States with over 1,500,000 new cases in 2016. Rates of new diagnoses continue to rise annually with an estimated increase of 4.7% from 2015 to 2016. Trends show that rates of chlamydia in females are 2 times higher than that of males. Rates are highest among adolescents and young adults. Racial disparities exist, and blacks are 5.6 times more commonly affected with chlamydia when compared to whites. Gonorrhea cases are more commonly seen in males, and there were an estimated 468,000 new cases of gonorrhea in 2016. Like with chlamydia, infections rates are higher in adolescents and young adults; the African American race is also disproportionately affected.

title: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Pathophysiology
content: The most common cause of NGU is chlamydia. C . trachomatis typically infects columnar epithelial cells at mucosal sites. It replicates in host cells eventually causing cell death. [4] Other causes of NGU are less well described.
contents: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Pathophysiology. The most common cause of NGU is chlamydia. C . trachomatis typically infects columnar epithelial cells at mucosal sites. It replicates in host cells eventually causing cell death. [4] Other causes of NGU are less well described.

title: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Histopathology
content: Microscopic evaluation of NGU reveals polymorphonuclear leukocytes without the presence of intracellular gram-negative diplococci on gram stain.
contents: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Histopathology. Microscopic evaluation of NGU reveals polymorphonuclear leukocytes without the presence of intracellular gram-negative diplococci on gram stain.

title: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Histopathology
content: The most common cause of NGU, C. trachomatis, is an intercellular bacterium. The cell wall in C. trachomatis lacks peptidoglycan. The absence of peptidoglycan makes C. trachomatis not visible on Gram stain and makes beta-lactam antimicrobials ineffective. [5]
contents: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Histopathology. The most common cause of NGU, C. trachomatis, is an intercellular bacterium. The cell wall in C. trachomatis lacks peptidoglycan. The absence of peptidoglycan makes C. trachomatis not visible on Gram stain and makes beta-lactam antimicrobials ineffective. [5]

title: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- History and Physical
content: Patients present with complaints of dysuria, pruritus, penile burning, and urethral discharge. Urethral discharge can be purulent, mucoid or watery. Discharge in NGU is sometimes scant and only noted as crusting at the meatus or staining of the underwear. Not all men with urethritis have symptoms, and over 40% of cases of all cases of NGU are asymptomatic. [6] Patients who present with regional lymphadenopathy, constitutional symptoms, or vesicles may have urethritis from HSV NGU.
contents: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- History and Physical. Patients present with complaints of dysuria, pruritus, penile burning, and urethral discharge. Urethral discharge can be purulent, mucoid or watery. Discharge in NGU is sometimes scant and only noted as crusting at the meatus or staining of the underwear. Not all men with urethritis have symptoms, and over 40% of cases of all cases of NGU are asymptomatic. [6] Patients who present with regional lymphadenopathy, constitutional symptoms, or vesicles may have urethritis from HSV NGU.

title: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- History and Physical
content: Physical examination may reveal penile discharge. Differentiating between gonococcal and non-gonococcal urethritis is difficult based on clinical examination of discharge. NGU tends to be mucoid or clear, compared to gonococcal urethritis which is more commonly purulent; however, this generalization is not reliable.
contents: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- History and Physical. Physical examination may reveal penile discharge. Differentiating between gonococcal and non-gonococcal urethritis is difficult based on clinical examination of discharge. NGU tends to be mucoid or clear, compared to gonococcal urethritis which is more commonly purulent; however, this generalization is not reliable.

title: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- History and Physical
content: Men with urethritis can also present with fever, testicular pain, testicular swelling, sore throat, rectal pain, or rectal discharge. Differential diagnoses of these symptoms would include other infectious processes such as epididymitis, pharyngitis, or prostatitis, and these should be considered accordingly. Conjunctivitis can accompany urethritis caused by gonorrhea, chlamydia, or Adenovirus .
contents: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- History and Physical. Men with urethritis can also present with fever, testicular pain, testicular swelling, sore throat, rectal pain, or rectal discharge. Differential diagnoses of these symptoms would include other infectious processes such as epididymitis, pharyngitis, or prostatitis, and these should be considered accordingly. Conjunctivitis can accompany urethritis caused by gonorrhea, chlamydia, or Adenovirus .

title: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- History and Physical
content: Some patients with NGU can also present with reactive arthritis, which is characterized by urethritis, uveitis, and arthritis. This constellation of symptoms is typically associated with the HLA-B27 gene. [1]
contents: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- History and Physical. Some patients with NGU can also present with reactive arthritis, which is characterized by urethritis, uveitis, and arthritis. This constellation of symptoms is typically associated with the HLA-B27 gene. [1]

title: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Evaluation
content: Urethritis can be diagnosed with any of the following: Mucoid, mucopurulent, or purulent discharge on examination Gram stain of urethral secretions demonstrating equal to 2 white blood cells (WBC) per oil immersion field Positive leukocyte esterase test on urinalysis or microscopic examination of sediment from a spun first-void urine demonstrating equal to 10 WBC per high-power field
contents: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Evaluation. Urethritis can be diagnosed with any of the following: Mucoid, mucopurulent, or purulent discharge on examination Gram stain of urethral secretions demonstrating equal to 2 white blood cells (WBC) per oil immersion field Positive leukocyte esterase test on urinalysis or microscopic examination of sediment from a spun first-void urine demonstrating equal to 10 WBC per high-power field

title: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Evaluation
content: The diagnosis of NGU requires the exclusion of gonorrheal infection. This can be achieved with a gram stain that lacks gram-negative diplococci or by any negative gonorrhea test (culture, nucleic acid testing, among others). [7]
contents: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Evaluation. The diagnosis of NGU requires the exclusion of gonorrheal infection. This can be achieved with a gram stain that lacks gram-negative diplococci or by any negative gonorrhea test (culture, nucleic acid testing, among others). [7]

title: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Evaluation
content: In men at high risk for infection, if symptoms are present but none of these criteria are met, a presumptive diagnosis can be made, and empiric treatment started. These patients should be treated with a drug regimen for both chlamydia and gonorrhea. [8]
contents: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Evaluation. In men at high risk for infection, if symptoms are present but none of these criteria are met, a presumptive diagnosis can be made, and empiric treatment started. These patients should be treated with a drug regimen for both chlamydia and gonorrhea. [8]

title: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Evaluation
content: Patients should also have a nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) performed for chlamydia, gonorrhea, and trichomoniasis. In urethritis, NAAT testing is recommended over culture because of its high sensitivity and specificity. NAAT testing for M. genitalium exists but is not widely available. [1]
contents: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Evaluation. Patients should also have a nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) performed for chlamydia, gonorrhea, and trichomoniasis. In urethritis, NAAT testing is recommended over culture because of its high sensitivity and specificity. NAAT testing for M. genitalium exists but is not widely available. [1]

title: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Treatment / Management
content: Empiric treatment for urethritis should be started at the time of diagnosis, before results of testing for a specific etiology. Treatment should be based on whether the gonococcal infection has been evaluated by microscope:
contents: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Treatment / Management. Empiric treatment for urethritis should be started at the time of diagnosis, before results of testing for a specific etiology. Treatment should be based on whether the gonococcal infection has been evaluated by microscope:

title: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Treatment / Management -- Recommended Regimens
content: Azithromycin 1 g orally in a single dose, or Doxycycline 100 mg orally twice a day for 7 days
contents: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Treatment / Management -- Recommended Regimens. Azithromycin 1 g orally in a single dose, or Doxycycline 100 mg orally twice a day for 7 days

title: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Treatment / Management
content: Azithromycin and doxycycline are both highly effective for the treatment for chlamydial urethritis. Urethritis associated with M. genitalium responds better to azithromycin, although azithromycin resistance is increasing.
contents: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Treatment / Management. Azithromycin and doxycycline are both highly effective for the treatment for chlamydial urethritis. Urethritis associated with M. genitalium responds better to azithromycin, although azithromycin resistance is increasing.

title: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Treatment / Management -- Presumptive Treatment of NGU without Microscope
content: When Gram stain is not available gonorrheal infection cannot be ruled out. These patients should be treated with a drug regimen effective against both chlamydia and gonorrhea.
contents: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Treatment / Management -- Presumptive Treatment of NGU without Microscope. When Gram stain is not available gonorrheal infection cannot be ruled out. These patients should be treated with a drug regimen effective against both chlamydia and gonorrhea.

title: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Treatment / Management -- Recommended Regimens
content: Ceftriaxone 250 mg IM PLUS Azithromycin 1 g orally in a single dose, or Doxycycline 100 mg orally twice a day for 7 days
contents: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Treatment / Management -- Recommended Regimens. Ceftriaxone 250 mg IM PLUS Azithromycin 1 g orally in a single dose, or Doxycycline 100 mg orally twice a day for 7 days

title: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Treatment / Management -- Recurrent or Persistent NGU
content: Recurrent or persistent symptoms can be common following treatment for NGU with the recommended regimen. Patients should first be evaluated for adherence to prior treatment and re-exposure to disease. If they continue to have evidence of urethritis (discharge on exam, elevated WBC on a microscope, or leukocyte esterase on urinalysis) therapy should be directed towards M. genitalium. M. genitalium is the most common cause of persistent or recurrent NGU.
contents: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Treatment / Management -- Recurrent or Persistent NGU. Recurrent or persistent symptoms can be common following treatment for NGU with the recommended regimen. Patients should first be evaluated for adherence to prior treatment and re-exposure to disease. If they continue to have evidence of urethritis (discharge on exam, elevated WBC on a microscope, or leukocyte esterase on urinalysis) therapy should be directed towards M. genitalium. M. genitalium is the most common cause of persistent or recurrent NGU.

title: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Treatment / Management -- Recommended Regimens
content: If azithromycin was not used for initial exposure: Azithromycin 1 g orally once If azithromycin was used for initial exposure Moxifloxacin 400 mg orally daily for 7 days In either instance, metronidazole 2 g orally once should be given in areas where T. vaginalis is prevalent. [1]
contents: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Treatment / Management -- Recommended Regimens. If azithromycin was not used for initial exposure: Azithromycin 1 g orally once If azithromycin was used for initial exposure Moxifloxacin 400 mg orally daily for 7 days In either instance, metronidazole 2 g orally once should be given in areas where T. vaginalis is prevalent. [1]

title: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Differential Diagnosis
content: The differential diagnosis of patients presenting with dysuria includes: Prostatitis Epididymitis Vaginitis Cystitis Typically, patients with another diagnosis present with other clinical findings; however, any of these conditions may also co-exist with urethritis. [9]
contents: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Differential Diagnosis. The differential diagnosis of patients presenting with dysuria includes: Prostatitis Epididymitis Vaginitis Cystitis Typically, patients with another diagnosis present with other clinical findings; however, any of these conditions may also co-exist with urethritis. [9]

title: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Treatment Planning
content: Partner management is recommended for patients with urethritis regardless of whether specific etiology is identified. Sexual partners within 60 days should be referred for complete STI evaluation and treatment with the same treatment regimen as the original patient. [1]
contents: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Treatment Planning. Partner management is recommended for patients with urethritis regardless of whether specific etiology is identified. Sexual partners within 60 days should be referred for complete STI evaluation and treatment with the same treatment regimen as the original patient. [1]

title: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Prognosis
content: NGU is generally a self-limited disease and resolves, even without therapy, with no complications in most cases.
contents: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Prognosis. NGU is generally a self-limited disease and resolves, even without therapy, with no complications in most cases.

title: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Complications
content: Complications for NGU in men are rare but include epididymitis, prostatitis, abscess formation, and reactive arthritis. One percent to 2% of males with NGU develop epididymitis. One percent to 2% develop conjunctivitis. Urethral stricture or stenosis is possible after NGU due to post inflammatory scar formation but is rare. Complications in women are more common than in men (10% to 40%). Women with urethritis can potentially develop pelvic inflammatory disease, infertility, and ectopic pregnancy. [10]
contents: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Complications. Complications for NGU in men are rare but include epididymitis, prostatitis, abscess formation, and reactive arthritis. One percent to 2% of males with NGU develop epididymitis. One percent to 2% develop conjunctivitis. Urethral stricture or stenosis is possible after NGU due to post inflammatory scar formation but is rare. Complications in women are more common than in men (10% to 40%). Women with urethritis can potentially develop pelvic inflammatory disease, infertility, and ectopic pregnancy. [10]

title: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Complications
content: Children born to mothers with chlamydia urethritis can potentially develop complications including conjunctivitis, iritis, and pneumonia. Routine treatment of all newborns with antibiotic eye ointment has significantly decreased the incidence of these. [11]
contents: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Complications. Children born to mothers with chlamydia urethritis can potentially develop complications including conjunctivitis, iritis, and pneumonia. Routine treatment of all newborns with antibiotic eye ointment has significantly decreased the incidence of these. [11]

title: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Complications
content: Chlamydia urethritis can also cause lymphogranuloma venereum, a genital ulcer disease which presents as lymphadenitis or lymphangitis and can lead to lymphatic obstruction, strictures or fistulas. [1]
contents: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Complications. Chlamydia urethritis can also cause lymphogranuloma venereum, a genital ulcer disease which presents as lymphadenitis or lymphangitis and can lead to lymphatic obstruction, strictures or fistulas. [1]

title: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Deterrence and Patient Education
content: Patient education should include the following: Patients should abstain from sexual activity for 7 days, starting after the completion of therapy for the patient and all partners. [1] Patients taking doxycycline should be advised to reduce sun exposure, as doxycycline can cause photosensitivity. [12] Patients taking metronidazole should be advised to avoid alcoholic beverages.
contents: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Deterrence and Patient Education. Patient education should include the following: Patients should abstain from sexual activity for 7 days, starting after the completion of therapy for the patient and all partners. [1] Patients taking doxycycline should be advised to reduce sun exposure, as doxycycline can cause photosensitivity. [12] Patients taking metronidazole should be advised to avoid alcoholic beverages.

title: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Pearls and Other Issues
content: Urethritis is typically a sexually transmitted infection with most cases caused by gonorrhea, chlamydia, and mycoplasma. Typical presentation includes dysuria and penile discharge. Diagnosis is based on positive discharge on an exam or more than 2 WBC seen on microscopy or presence of leukocytes on urinalysis  (or 10 WBC on first-void urine catch).
contents: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Pearls and Other Issues. Urethritis is typically a sexually transmitted infection with most cases caused by gonorrhea, chlamydia, and mycoplasma. Typical presentation includes dysuria and penile discharge. Diagnosis is based on positive discharge on an exam or more than 2 WBC seen on microscopy or presence of leukocytes on urinalysis  (or 10 WBC on first-void urine catch).

title: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Pearls and Other Issues
content: Initial empiric treatment should be started at the time of diagnosis. Treatment for NGU when gonococcal infection can be rule out based on microscope examination includes azithromycin 1 g orally once or doxycycline 100 mg twice per day for 7 days. If a gonococcal infection cannot be ruled out treatment should add ceftriaxone 250 mg intramuscularly once to cover for gonococcal infection. Patients should be instructed to avoid sex for 1 week and until partners are treated. Partners should be tested and treated for urethritis.
contents: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Pearls and Other Issues. Initial empiric treatment should be started at the time of diagnosis. Treatment for NGU when gonococcal infection can be rule out based on microscope examination includes azithromycin 1 g orally once or doxycycline 100 mg twice per day for 7 days. If a gonococcal infection cannot be ruled out treatment should add ceftriaxone 250 mg intramuscularly once to cover for gonococcal infection. Patients should be instructed to avoid sex for 1 week and until partners are treated. Partners should be tested and treated for urethritis.

title: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Enhancing Healthcare Team Outcomes
content: Patients with urethritis may present to the emergency department, urgent care clinic, or primary care provider. It is important for these healthcare professionals to be aware of the cause of urethritis and its treatment. In many cases, the treatment is empirical until the laboratory has confirmed the diagnosis. Patients should be instructed to avoid sex for 1 week and until partners are treated. Partners should be tested and treated for urethritis.
contents: Nongonococcal Urethritis -- Enhancing Healthcare Team Outcomes. Patients with urethritis may present to the emergency department, urgent care clinic, or primary care provider. It is important for these healthcare professionals to be aware of the cause of urethritis and its treatment. In many cases, the treatment is empirical until the laboratory has confirmed the diagnosis. Patients should be instructed to avoid sex for 1 week and until partners are treated. Partners should be tested and treated for urethritis.
